awd_titl_txt: Conference: Groundwork for Operator Algebras Lecture Series (GOALS) 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
Operator algebras arose as a mathematical framework for quantum mechanics and today is a highly active research area. The Groundwork for Operator Algebras Lecture Series (GOALS) will provide early-career graduate students with an introduction to the fundamental techniques and current research in operator algebras. In addition, GOALS aims to increase, in this field, the participation and retention of persons from traditionally underrepresented groups by removing technical barriers to the field and building a strong community of support among the participants, contributors, and organizers. 
 
Operator algebras is a branch of functional analysis, which has a long-standing dialogue with various fields of mathematics and physics, such as topology, group theory, conformal field theory, probability, and logic, to name a few.  As this list indicates, the breadth of knowledge required to actively engage in operator algebras can be intimidating; hence the need for GOALS as stated above. The objectives of GOALS will be accomplished via lecture series on the basics of C*-algebras and von Neumann algebras; problem sessions; evening discussions on psychological barriers; expository talks about more advanced topics; and a culminating conference with leading researchers in operator algebras.  The community created at GOALS 2022 will be sustained by providing financial support for the participants to reunite at major annual operator algebras conferences such as the Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium in May 2023. More details about GOALS are available at https://users.math.msu.edu/users/banelson/conferences/GOALS.html

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Using a combination of mini-courses, problem sessions, and expository talks, GOALS 2022 provided early-career mathematics graduate students with an accelerated introduction to the basics of operator algebras and a professional support network within the operator algebras community. 

The self-reported demographic information for the 20 GOALS 2022 students is as follows: (Gender) 7 participants identified as female, 3 as nonbinary/transgender, and 10 as male; (Race) 7 students identified as Asian and 11 as white; (Ethnicity) 5 students identified as Hispanic or Latino.

GOALS 2022 dramatically increased the students’ comfort level with both C*-algebras and von Neumann algebras: 10 of the 18 respondents to the GOALS 2022 exit survey felt comfortable or very comfortable with von Neumann algebras after GOALS, while only three could say  the same before the program. Similarly, 13 exit survey respondents reported feeling comfortable or very comfortable with C*-algebras after GOALS, an increase of 9 from the pre-GOALS number.

GOALS participation also augmented the students’ enthusiasm for operator algebras; nearly 90% of the exit survey respondents plan to work in operator algebras, and the expository lectures and culminating workshop left the same number “enthusiastic and excited about all the different flavors of operator algebras.”  Similarly, 78% of the exit survey respondents reported that participating in GOALS increased their confidence in their mathematical abilities.

A major objective of GOALS 2022 was to create a supportive community for the GOALS participants, and in this vein the participants considered GOALS 2022 a resounding success. 94% of the GOALS 2022 exit survey respondents agreed that GOALS 2022 created a welcoming community, and all the respondents felt that GOALS had strengthened their professional network. Several participants explicitly praised the community created at GOALS 2022, with one respondent saying "I have been having a hard time trying to find a community within mathematics and now I feel like I have an incredible community of new friends." A monthly GOALS Seminar, held over Zoom and followed by a social hour, has helped maintain the GOALS community. We also held a GOALS reunion event at the 2023  Great Plains Operator Theory Symposium (GPOTS), which was attended by 6 of the GOALS 2022 students as well as 12 students from previous GOALS iterations.

A more tangible product of GOALS is the GOALS lecture notes, written by the organizers and publicly available on the GOALS website. All but one of the GOALS 2022 exit survey respondents planned to continue studying these lecture notes in future.  We have also encouraged non-GOALS students and researchers to use the notes as a self-contained, accessible introduction to operator algebras.

Modified by: Rolando De Santiago
